member.name: T:Moq.Language.IThrows
member.summary: Defines the Throws verb.

member.name: M:Moq.Language.IThrows.Throws(System.Exception)
member.summary: Specifies the exception to throw when the method is invoked.
member.param: Exception instance to throw.
member.example:
This example shows how to throw an exception when the method is invoked with an empty string argument:
mock.Expect(x => x.Execute("")) .Throws(new ArgumentException());

member.name: T:Moq.Language.IVerifies
member.summary: Defines the Verifiable verb.

member.name: M:Moq.Language.IVerifies.Verifiable
member.summary: Marks the expectation as verifiable, meaning that a call to will check if this particular expectation was met.
member.example:
The following example marks the expectation as verifiable:
mock.Expect(x => x.Execute("ping")) .Returns(true) .Verifiable();

member.name: T:Moq.MockException
member.summary: Exception thrown by mocks when expectations are not met, the mock is not properly setup, etc.
member.remarks:
A distinct exception type is provided so that exceptions thrown by the mock can be differentiated in tests that expect other exceptions to be thrown (i.e. ArgumentException).
Richer exception hierarchy/types are not provided as tests typically should not catch or expect exceptions from the mocks. These are typically the result of changes in the tested class or its collaborators implementation, and result in fixes in the mock setup so that they dissapear and allow the test to pass.

member.summary: Supports the serialization infrastructure.

member.name: T:Moq.MockFactory
member.summary: Utility factory class to use to construct multiple mocks when consistent behavior and verification is desired for all of them.
member.remarks:
If multiple mocks will be created during a test, passing the desired (if different than the ) and later verifying each mock can become repetitive and tedious.
This factory class helps in that scenario by providing a simplified creation of multiple mocks with the exact same and posterior verification.

member.name: M:Moq.MockFactory.#ctor(Moq.MockBehavior)
member.summary: Initializes the factory with the given for newly created mocks from the factory.
member.param: The behavior to use for mocks created using the factory method

member.name: M:Moq.MockFactory.Create``1
member.summary: Creates a new mock with the specified at factory construction time.
member.typeparam: Type to mock.

member.name: M:Moq.MockFactory.Create``1(System.Object[])
member.summary: Creates a new mock with the specified at factory construction time and with the the given constructor arguments for the class.
member.remarks: The mock will try to find the best match constructor given the constructor arguments, and invoke that to initialize the instance. This applies only to classes, not interfaces.
member.typeparam: Type to mock.

member.name: M:Moq.MockFactory.Verify
member.summary: Verifies all verifiable expectations on all mocks created by this factory.
member.exception: One or more mocks had expectations that were not satisfied.

member.name: M:Moq.MockFactory.VerifyAll
member.summary: Verifies all verifiable expectations on all mocks created by this factory.
member.exception: One or more mocks had expectations that were not satisfied.

member.name: T:Moq.MockBehavior
member.summary: Options to customize the behavior of the mock.

member.name: F:Moq.MockBehavior.Strict
member.summary: Causes the mock to always throw an exception for invocations that don't have a corresponding expectation.

member.name: F:Moq.MockBehavior.Normal
member.summary: Matches the behavior of classes and interfaces in equivalent manual mocks: abstract methods need to have an expectation (override), as well as all interface members. Other members (virtual and non-virtual) can be called freely and will end up invoking the implementation on the target type if available.

member.name: F:Moq.MockBehavior.Relaxed
member.summary: Will only throw exceptions for abstract methods and interface members which need to return a value and don't have a corresponding expectation.

member.name: F:Moq.MockBehavior.Loose
member.summary: Will never throw exceptions, returning default values when necessary (null for reference types or zero for value types).

member.name: F:Moq.MockBehavior.Default
member.summary: Default mock behavior, which equals .

member.name: T:Moq.Mock`1
member.summary: Provides a mock implementation of .
member.remarks:
If the mocked is a (such as a Windows Forms control or another -derived class) all members will be mockeable, even if they are not virtual or abstract.
For regular .NET classes ("POCOs" or Plain Old CLR Objects), only abstract and virtual members can be mocked.
The behavior of the mock with regards to the expectations and the actual calls is determined by the optional that can be passed to the constructor.

member.name: T:Moq.IVerifiable
member.devdoc: Internal interface implemented by Mock{T} to enable to verify mocks in a generic way.

member.name: M:Moq.Mock`1.#ctor(Moq.MockBehavior,System.Object[])
member.summary: Initializes an instance of the mock with a specific behavior with the given constructor arguments for the class.
member.remarks:
The mock will try to find the best match constructor given the constructor arguments, and invoke that to initialize the instance. This applies only to classes, not interfaces.
Note: For a derived class, any calls done in the constructor itself (i.e. calls to private members, initialization methods, etc. invoked from the constructor) will not go through the proxied mock and will instead be direct invocations in the underlying object. This is a known limitation.

member.name: M:Moq.Mock`1.#ctor(System.Object[])
member.summary: Initializes an instance of the mock with default behavior and with the given constructor arguments for the class. (Only valid when is a class)
member.remarks:
The mock will try to find the best match constructor given the constructor arguments, and invoke that to initialize the instance. This applies only for classes, not interfaces.
Note: For a derived class, any calls done in the constructor itself will not go through the proxied mock and will instead be direct invocations in the underlying object. This is known limitation.

member.name: M:Moq.Mock`1.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes an instance of the mock with default behavior.

member.name: M:Moq.Mock`1.#ctor(Moq.MockBehavior)
member.summary: Initializes an instance of the mock with the specified behavior.

member.name: M:Moq.Mock`1.Expect(System.Linq.Expressions.Expression{System.Action{`0}})
member.summary: Sets an expectation on the mocked type for a call to to a void method.
member.remarks: If more than one expectation is set for the same method or property, the latest one wins and is the one that will be executed.
member.param: Lambda expression that specifies the expected method invocation.

example.code: var mock = new Mock<IProcessor>(); mock.Expect(x => x.Execute("ping"));

member.name: M:Moq.Mock`1.Expect``1(System.Linq.Expressions.Expression{System.Func{`0,``0}})
member.summary: Sets an expectation on the mocked type for a call to to a value returning method.
member.remarks: If more than one expectation is set for the same method or property, the latest one wins and is the one that will be executed.
member.param: Lambda expression that specifies the expected method invocation.

member.name: M:Moq.Mock`1.Verify
member.summary: Verifies that all verifiable expectations have been met.
member.exception: Not all verifiable expectations were met.

member.name: M:Moq.Mock`1.VerifyAll
member.summary: Verifies all expectations regardless of whether they have been flagged as verifiable.
member.exception: At least one expectation was not met.

member.remarks:
If the mocked is a (such as a Windows Forms control or another -derived class) all members will be mockeable, even if they are not virtual or abstract.
For regular .NET classes ("POCOs" or Plain Old CLR Objects), only abstract and virtual members can be mocked.
The behavior of the mock with regards to the expectations and the actual calls is determined by the optional that can be passed to the constructor.

member.name: T:Moq.It
member.summary: Allows the specification of a matching condition for an argument in a method invocation, rather than a specific argument value. "It" refers to the argument being matched.
member.remarks: This class allows the expectation to match a method invocation with an arbitrary value, with a value in a specified range, or even one that matches a given predicate.

member.name: M:Moq.It.IsAny``1
member.summary: Matches any value of the given type.
member.remarks: Typically used when the actual argument value for a method call is not relevant.

example.code: // Throws an exception for a call to Remove with any string value. mock.Expect(x => x.Remove(It.IsAny<string>())).Throws(new InvalidOperationException());

member.name: M:Moq.It.Is``1(System.Linq.Expressions.Expression{System.Predicate{``0}})
member.summary: Matches any value that satisfies the given predicate.
member.typeparam: Type of the argument to check.
member.param: The predicate used to match the method argument.
member.remarks: Allows the specification of a predicate to perform matching of method call arguments.

member.name: M:Moq.It.IsInRange``1(``0,``0,Moq.Range)
member.summary: Matches any value that is in the range specified.
member.typeparam: Type of the argument to check.
member.param: The lower bound of the range.
The upper bound of the range.
The kind of range. See .

member.name: T:Moq.RemotingProxy
member.summary: Adapter for Remoting interception. It allows invocation of the underlying proxied object if a given member is not abstract on the target type.

member.name: T:Moq.RemotingProxy.NullInterceptor
member.summary: We use a null interceptor for the generated class as we'll be already intercepting through remoting, which is more powerful and gives us additional interception points (private members, non-virtuals, etc.).

member.name: T:Moq.ExpressionVisitor
member.summary: Base class for visitors of expression trees.
member.remarks:
Provides the functionality of the internal visitor base class that comes with Linq.
Matt's comments on the implementation:
In this variant there is only one visitor class that dispatches calls to the general Visit function out to specific VisitXXX methods corresponding to different node types. Note not every node type gets it own method, for example all binary operators are treated in one VisitBinary method. The nodes themselves do not directly participate in the visitation process. They are treated as just data. The reason for this is that the quantity of visitors is actually open ended. You can write your own. Therefore no semantics of visiting is coupled into the node classes. Its all in the visitors. The default visit behavior for node XXX is baked into the base classs version of VisitXXX.
Another variant is that all VisitXXX methods return a node. The Expression tree nodes are immutable. In order to change the tree you must construct a new one. The default VisitXXX methods will construct a new node if any of its sub-trees change. If no changes are made then the same node is returned. That way if you make a change to a node (by making a new node) deep down in a tree, the rest of the tree is rebuilt automatically for you.
See: http://blogs.msdn.com/mattwar/archive/2007/07/31/linq-building-an-iqueryable-provider-part-ii.aspx.
member.author: Matt Warren: http://blogs.msdn.com/mattwar
